name: Haiti
currentCrisisSummary:
Haiti endures a **catastrophic collapse of governance and society**, directly driven by centuries of **foreign intervention, economic extraction, and elite impunity**. A near-total implosion of state functions allows armed gangsâ€”often linked to elitesâ€”to control vast areas, imposing **extortion, mass violence, and displacement**. Humanitarian access is blocked by insecurity, producing acute hunger and rising mortality.

An internationally backed, Kenyan-led mission deployed to assist police faces constraints and contested legitimacy. The crisis is rooted in **colonial expropriation, odious debt enforced by France, repeated US occupations, and neoliberal policies** that deliberately undermined Haitian agriculture and sovereignty, leaving the population in a state of extreme vulnerability.

colonialRoot.legacy:
Haiti's modern fragility traces back to the international reaction to the Haitian Revolution. The world's first Black republic was diplomatically isolated, economically pressured and forced to buy recognition.

In 1825 France imposed an indemnity on Haiti to 'compensate' former slaveholders. Financed through foreign loans and paid over generations, the indemnity drained the new state's resources and entrenched dependency â€” a formative example of how post-colonial debt has been used to perpetuate extraction and limit sovereign development.

historicalContext.title: Post-Colonial Debt and Extraction
historicalContext.description:
The 1825 indemnity established a pattern of external economic control that shaped Haiti's fiscal and development trajectory. Successive loans, debt-servicing obligations and mercantilist trade pressures channelled wealth outwards rather than funding broad-based investment, undermining agricultural resilience, infrastructure and state capacity.

These structural pressures were reinforced across the 19th and 20th centuries by discriminatory trade policies, foreign business interests and conditional financial relations that favoured foreign capital over local development.

historicalContext.title: Foreign Intervention and Occupation
historicalContext.description:
Foreign interventions have repeatedly undermined Haitian sovereignty. The US occupation (1915-1934) centralised fiscal control, moved gold reserves offshore and rewrote key legal frameworks to favour foreign interests. Later international economic prescriptionsâ€”most notoriously, the reduction of tariffs on imported US rice, which destroyed local rice farming and created chronic food dependencyâ€”weakened domestic agriculture and industry, increasing dependence on imports and external aid.

International actors have also played direct political roles, including support for coups and pressure on elected governments, leaving Haiti with chronically weakened institutions and limited capacity to manage recurrent shocks.

historicalContext.title: Cold War Dictatorship and US Patronage
historicalContext.description: For nearly three decades (1957-1986), Haiti was ruled by the brutal and kleptocratic Duvalier family dictatorship. As a staunchly anti-communist regime in close proximity to Cuba, the Duvaliers were largely supported and funded by the United States as a Cold War client. This imperial patronage allowed the regime to terrorise the population and loot the state, further hollowing out institutions and entrenching a model of violent, predatory rule that benefited foreign interests.

historicalContext.title: Public Health and Unresponsibility
historicalContext.description: International presence has also inflicted direct harm: UN peacekeepers inadvertently introduced a cholera epidemic in 2010 that caused thousands of deaths and provoked a protracted public health disaster for which the UN has since acknowledged responsibility. This episode deepened mistrust of international actors and highlighted the risks of poorly governed external interventions.

historicalContext.title: International Law And Accountability
historicalContext.description: There are multiple accountability threads â€” historical (the 1825 indemnity and colonial expropriation), transitional (investigations into the 2021 assassination of President MoÃ¯se), and contemporaneous (documentation of human-rights abuses by gangs and by public actors). Formal international responses, including human-rights monitoring and UN Security Council authorisations for multilateral missions, exist but face political contestation and remain insufficient to meet victims' demands for justice and reparations.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 5,600 killed in 2024 alone, victims of **escalating gang violence fuelled by elite impunity and state collapse.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Approximately 6 million people require aid to survive the **consequences of political instability and economic devastation imposed by external actors and local elites.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Roughly 5.7 million face acute hunger, a direct result of **neoliberal policies destroying local agriculture and current gang blockades.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 1.3 million internally displaced (a record high), **driven from homes by gang terror enabled by state failure.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: Hundreds of thousands forced to flee the country by **violence and economic desperation rooted in foreign interference**, often facing deportation.

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: Many health facilities non-functional due to **direct attacks and the general breakdown of public services caused by chronic underfunding and instability.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Lack of Water Access
humanitarianImpact.description: Millions lack safe drinking water and sanitation because of the **disintegration of infrastructure resulting from historical debt burdens and state incapacity.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Education Disrupted
humanitarianImpact.description: Hundreds of thousands of children denied education due to **pervasive insecurity and the collapse of the state's ability to provide basic services.**

timeline.event: **The 'Pearl of the Antilles'**: Saint-Domingue becomes the most profitable colony in the Americas, producing vast sugar and coffee wealth built on the labour of enslaved Africans.
**Haitian Revolution**: Enslaved people and free Black insurgents overthrow colonial rule, culminating in independence and the world's first Black republic.

**French Indemnity**: Under threat of military action, Haiti agrees to pay France an indemnity to secure diplomatic recognition. The payments, financed with foreign loans, imposed a long-term fiscal burden on the new state.

**US Occupation**: US Marines occupy Haiti, centralise fiscal control, move reserves overseas and rework institutions in ways that served foreign commercial interests and weakened sovereign governance.

**Duvalier Dictatorship**: Backed by the US as a Cold War ally against communism, the brutal dictatorship of 'Papa Doc' and 'Baby Doc' Duvalier terrorises the population and loots the state for 29 years.

**Neoliberal Shock & Food Dependency**: Following the end of the dictatorship, IMF and US pressure forces Haiti to slash tariffs on imported rice. Subsidised US rice floods the market, destroying local agriculture and creating long-term food import dependency.

**Coup d'Ã‰tat**: Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the country's first democratically elected president, is ousted in a coup with the backing of the US, France, and Canada, leading to a UN occupation (MINUSTAH).

**Earthquake & Cholera**: A catastrophic earthquake kills over 200,000 people. In the disaster's aftermath UN peacekeepers introduce cholera to Haiti, causing thousands of deaths and a prolonged public-health crisis for which the UN later accepted responsibility.
**Assassination of President MoÃ¯se**: The killing of Jovenel MoÃ¯se deepens political instability and accelerates the collapse of security institutions, contributing to expanding gang control.

**Gang Siege and International Mission**: Violent gang campaigns seize large parts of Port-au-Prince, triggering mass displacement and extreme suffering. A Kenyan-led, UN-backed mission deploys amidst controversy over its mandate and legitimacy.

donate.description: A Haitian organisation providing financial inclusion, livelihoods and community development services to rural families.
WFP delivers emergency food and nutrition assistance in Haiti and coordinates food security response efforts.

advocacy: Demand financial reparations and a serious, public accounting from France for the harms and long-term economic damage caused by the 1825 indemnity.
Oppose external military interventions that undermine Haitian sovereignty unless they are accountable, properly mandated and centred on civilian protection and Haitian consent.
Support Haitian-led peasant movements and campaigns for food sovereignty and oppose trade and aid policies that privilege imports over local agriculture.
Push for full accountability for the UN's role in the cholera epidemic and for reparative measures, while supporting locally led public-health rebuilding.
Amplify Haitian civil-society voices and fund Haitian organisations directly to ensure aid reaches affected communities and strengthens local capacity.

reading.description: C. L. R. James's classic history of the Haitian Revolution and its global significance.

reading.title: The Uses of Haiti
reading.description: Paul Farmer's critique of international policy and humanitarian response in Haiti over several decades.

reading.title: Haiti: The Aftershocks of History
reading.description: Laurent Dubois's accessible history of Haiti from the revolution through contemporary crises.
